skill.name: rdkit
skill.description: Cheminformatics toolkit for fine-grained molecular control. SMILES/SDF parsing, descriptors (MW, LogP, TPSA), fingerprints, substructure search, 2D/3D generation, similarity, reactions. For standard workflows with simpler interface, use datamol (wrapper around RDKit). Use rdkit for advanced control, custom sanitization, specialized algorithms.

content.value_statement: Drug discovery requires analyzing thousands of molecular structures for properties like solubility and drug-likeness. RDKit provides comprehensive tools to parse molecular formats, calculate descriptors, and visualize chemical structures.
actual_capabilities: Parse molecular formats: SMILES, SDF, MOL, InChI
Compute molecular fingerprints for similarity analysis
Apply chemical reactions and transform molecules
limitations: Requires RDKit installation (conda install -c conda-forge rdkit)
Not suitable for quantum mechanical calculations

prompt_templates.title: Calculate properties
prompt_templates.prompt: Read the SMILES string CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O and calculate its molecular weight, LogP, and number of hydrogen bond donors

prompt_templates.title: Find similar compounds
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate Morgan fingerprints for these SMILES and find pairs with >0.7 similarity: CC(=O)O, CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1, CC(C)CC1=CC=C(C=C1)C(C)C(=O)O

prompt_templates.title: Filter by substructure

prompt_templates.prompt: Generate 10 conformers for cyclohexane and optimize them with MMFF force field, then calculate RMSD between first two conformers

best_practices: Always check if MolFromSmiles returns None before processing molecules
Use bulk operations like BulkTanimotoSimilarity for better performance on large datasets
Pickle processed molecules to avoid re-parsing large files
anti_patterns: Don't assume molecules are valid - check for None after parsing
Avoid loading entire SDF files into memory - use ForwardSDMolSupplier for large files
Don't mix 2D and 3D operations without appropriate coordinate generation

faq.question: What molecular formats does RDKit support?
faq.answer: SMILES, SDF, MOL, MOL2, PDB, InChI, and peptide sequences. SMILES is most common for text-based storage.

faq.question: How do I install RDKit?
faq.answer: Use conda: conda install -c conda-forge rdkit. It's not available via pip due to C++ dependencies.

faq.question: What's the difference between SMILES and SMARTS?
faq.answer: SMILES represents specific molecules. SMARTS is a pattern language for substructure searching with wildcards.

faq.question: Why is my molecule None after parsing?
faq.answer: Check for invalid chemistry (valence errors), aromaticity issues, or syntax errors in the SMILES string.

faq.question: Which fingerprint should I use?
faq.answer: Morgan fingerprints (radius 2) are standard for similarity. MACCS keys for quick screens. RDKit for 2D similarity.

faq.question: How can I speed up large dataset processing?
faq.answer: Use MultithreadedSDMolSupplier for parallel parsing, pickle molecules after processing, and use bulk similarity calculations.
